section.subtitle: Two Movements of the Moon
section.para: TODO: (sub)titles of laws should be in the table of contents. TODO: Honorifics in bibliography has a dot after it! TODO: Edition in bibliography is printed lonly. TODO: Specify san-serif font with Hebrew. TODO: Why are degrees numbers hanging? The moon has two mean movements. The moon itself rotates on a small circle that does not surround all of the Earth. Moon's movement on that small circle is called mean lunar anomaly (אמצע המסלול). The small circle (epicycle) itself rotates on a big circle (deferent) that surrounds the Earth. The mean movement of the small circle on the big circle that surrounds the Earth is called mean lunar longitude (אמצע הירח).

section.title: Law 1
section.subtitle: Doubled Distance
section.para: To find true lunar longitude (הירח האמיתי) on a specific day: First, calculate mean lunar longitude during observation time of the desired night. Also, calculate mean lunar anomaly and mean solar longitude for the same time. Then, subtract mean solar longitude from the mean lunar longitude and double the result. This value is called doubled distance (מרחק הכפול).

section.title: Law 2,3
section.subtitle: Correction of the Mean Anomaly
section.para:
We already stipulated that all the calculations in these chapters are for one purpose only: to know if the moon is visible. And it is not possible for this double distance during the night of observation when the moon is indeed visible to be outside of the interval from 5° to 62°. It cannot be more - nor less.
This is Law 2.
In this light, contemplate this doubled distance. This is the correction of mean lunar anomaly depending on the doubled distance:
Result of adding this correction (TODO: mnas?!) to the mean lunar anomaly is called corrected lunar anomaly (מסלול הנכון).

Rambam does not describe the model behind this correction. Because the models Rambam did describe until now are the same as Almagest's models (including numerical parameters), and because this correction is determined by the (doubled) sun-moon elongation, just like Almagest's "improved" model of the moon ("the crank"), I assume that that model was used to calculate this correction. It seems that Rambam treats "the crank" as just a calculation device - otherwise, table giving visible anomaly from the corrected anomaly should take into account changes in the earth-moon distance depending on the elongation - and it does not! Maybe that is why he does not describe the model behind this correction. And maybe this is why Rambam reiterates - in Law 2 - that only the observability of the new moon needs to be calculated correctly. TODO: How does Almagest calculate visible anomaly?

section.title: Law 4,5,6
section.subtitle: Visible Anomaly
section.para:
Afterwards, see how many degrees is corrected lunar anomaly. If it is less than 180°, subtract mnas of this corrected anomaly from the mean lunar longitude the observation time. An if corrected lunar anomaly is more than 180° but less than 360°, add mnas of this corrected anomaly to the mean lunar longitude the observation time. And mean lunar longitude after you add to it or subtract from it is the true lunar longitude at the observation time.
This is Law 4.

You should know that if the corrected anomaly is 180° or 360°, it does not have a mona (TODO: visible anomaly?), so mean lunar longitude at the observation time is also true longitude.
This is Law 5.
What is the value of the visible anomaly for a given value of the corrected anomaly?

Formulae: R - radius of the big circle; r - radius of the small circle; e = R/r. A little trigonometry, and we get: visible anomaly = arctg(sin(corrected anomaly)/(cos(corrected anomaly) + e)) and: e = ctg(visible anomaly)*sin(corrected anomaly) - cos(corrected anomaly)
